commentBody: Once again, Wordplay is not accessible from the main puzzles page.
55 across, interesting choice. Not sure how I feel about it.

First-round voting for the 2024 Puzzle of the Year awards ends tomorrow! Nominees are in four groups: Early Week (Monday‚ÄìWednesday), Thursday, Themeless (Friday & Saturday) and Sunday. In this first round, you may select up to five puzzles in each group. The five puzzles receiving the most votes will move on to the second round of voting. Here's the link to the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059 Many thanks to everyone who nominated a puzzle. Thanks also to John Ezra and Cat Lady Margaret for their help with this project. If the third-party ballot doesn't work for some reason, blame me and not John or Margaret.

Fastest Friday in some time.

Hope everyone else finds the column and comments..
Fun, zippy puzzle. Loved 41A especially. But seemed much too easy for a Friday. I did it in more like a Tuesday or Wednesday time. It‚Äôs inspiring to see a debut constructor! Congrats!

Crossword Revolution D3:  ROSA PARKS

After we ran into a POTHOLE, we caught a bus and carried on.

* A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.  All rights reserved, including those that are, you know, literally in the Constitution.

Judging by the column and the actions of the Puzzles Dept., the goal of the NYT is to have a year with 365 debut puzzles.  Meanwhile at the New Yorker, you can regularly find puzzles by veteran favorites like Robyn Weintraub, Paolo Pasco, Barbara Lin, Erik Agard, Andy Kravis, Aimee Lucido, Elizabeth Gorski, Patrick Berry, etc.  The most recent Patrick Berry NYT was in 2018!  2018!!!  The last Liz Gorski in the NYT?  2016!!!

Honestly, which do you think is better?  Would you rather go to a concert featuring Paul Simon, Elton John, Beyonce, Paul McCartney, Billy Joel, James Taylor and Taylor Swift, or seven artists who have just released their debut single?  Think about it.

Something to ponder.

It took me awhile to get into this one, but once I got THISISNOTAPIPE (a gimme for me thanks to my art conservator daughter) the puzzle just fell right into place.  Getting CASTE for drone bees, which was my final entry, had me scratching my head for a minute, but it actually makes perfect sense.

Although I enjoyed both the Thursday and Friday puzzles, I‚Äôm hoping for a tough Saturday.

At first I thought the ‚Äúnondairy offering‚Äù was yet another clue for our ubiquitous cookie, haha.

When I found my mistake, I cried ‚ÄúCeci n‚Äôest pas un Oreo!‚Äù

Delightful Friday puzzle. A little slower than my average for Fridays, but really it was finding a good section to get my teeth into. Today was bottom left across and then up. I want to add that I was offended by posts earlier this week that the comments section is for whiners. Comments is for people to express their opinions. Generally speaking many comments lately have been regarding the ease or lack of ease with Monday puzzles. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs whining when you‚Äôre discussing something that is common knowledge and understanding with Times crossword puzzles. Monday puzzles are understood to be easiest of the week with almost no harder clues.

Constructor here, hope everyone has fun with today's puzzle! Glad most here seem to enjoy it.

Some other harder (maybe) clues that didn't make the cut

1D One of two in a chest
8D Acronym that omits the word "acid"
24D What cars or genes might do 
50A Notable sit-in protester

Not sure how to ping but @Deb, my name is misspelled in the first line.

THIS IS NOT A PIPE.

Quirky and surreal, and somehow appropriate these days.

I don't pretend to understand Magritte's art, but I like it.


Magritte and the Flintstones make a good puzzle.
Thank you, Ernest Lim.

Zipped right through this entertaining maze. Who knew OSIRIS has green skin? ‚ÄúSix-letter god starting with O‚Äù is how I got it. 

No music. Flyspeck. Looked hard at the change I‚Äôd made in the southeast to accommodate OPENENDEd. Considered OPENENDER, Figured I must‚Äôve missed something else. Shrugged, checked puzzle. 

Sigh. There‚Äôs more than one reason my streaks are so limited

Very doable Friday. Keep your patience and your faith in yourself.  

Also, ocala is the answer you seek to unlock the western mids.

Very sweet that we find DONUT whose shape is a torus, next to TAURUS, with which you can do donuts (if so inclined). Yes, the exit polls told one story, but what I hope makes headlines in this evening's late edition is that we drone bees of the worker castes, who scrum for a living alongside our Latin neighbors, the children of Rosa Parks and the poor women no longer in control of their own uteri lest they end up in the state pen, doing jobs where we're always pressed for time, just found out that we will BEAR THE EXPENSE of all this. To think, the Flinstones were more enlightened than we are. This is not a pipe, it's a pipe dream! OK, John Ezra, rein it in. Back to the cowshed you go. Right. Don't forget to fill out the ballot for the PUZZLE OF THE YEAR FOR 2024 awards, the Griddies. Voting for the first round is over Midnight the 24th (Oceania Time). The Griddies can be accessed here: https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059

This one seems like another one of THOSE puzzles that was harder to construct than to solve.  A lot of the fills were revealed before I read the clues, and It all was done in under half an hour, before I really got settled into it‚Äîunfamiliar territory for me on a Friday.  CASTE was my last entry, and I would guess that EXITPOLLS might confirm it was for many others as well.

Nevertheless, I did enjoy solving it, and I found the fills fun and imaginative.  Thank you, Eric Lim, and I'm sure we will be seeing other puzzles from you.
Nice puzzle, Ernest!  Enjoyed the clever clues, with ‚Äúrun for your honey‚Äù being my favorite. Congratulations on your debut.

For once I resisted the urge to look up stuff in a late week puzzle - and I managed to fill the grid all on my own! It took 31 minutes but I'm quite proud of the feat. Can you imagine how badly I wanted to Google the Magritte thing? Or the Florida city? The first I got largely from crosses, and the latter I dredged up from some dark recess of my mind with just the _C___ there. A miracle if there ever was one. 

The last square to fall was RO_/_ELT. For the longest time I just could not parse "mug" as in a mugger's verb, and I'm not sure I knew BELT as a big swig before. 

Anyway, I enjoyed the puzzle. I found the difficulty just right for a Friday.
Congratulations on a fine NYT debut, Mr. Lim! Nicely done!

This was a delectable puzzle for a sweet start to the weekend. 
Very mellow and enjoyable. 

Ah, CEDARWOOD. How I love the aroma! It had me wishing for a scratch-and-sniff button on my screen.

It also delighted me to see both Magritte and Jackson Pollock in the puzzle, as if I were standing in front of their art. 
Neither of their works are specifically to my liking, but I greatly appreciate their uniqueness and existence.

I also greatly appreciated this puzzle which was indeed to my liking.
Thank you, Mr. Lim, and congratulations on your debut!
Congratulations to Mr. Lim for an excellent puzzle. Nice wordplay with few if any obscure actors, singers or exotic cuisine. Bravo!
Overall easy and fast for a Friday, but OPENENDER? With an R? I am closed to that possibility. Harumph.
An enjoyable enough puzzle but it was a Tuesday level of difficulty.

"Can't you iron my clothes?"
"No, I'm pressed for time."

("Now I'm steamed.")

And now for a word from your friendly neighborhood pedant. 

Just an FYI. Honey bee drones are not a caste. 

Per "The Beekeepers Handbook, fifth edition", by Diana Sammataro and Alphonse Avitabile on page 26: "Caste in social insects is applied to individuals of the same sex that differ both in behavior and morphology ... Drones, the male bees, are not members of a caste, since all drones exhibit the same morphology and behavior."

It's still a fine clue because caste is commonly (mis)used that way.

I really enjoyed this one.  It seemed "tight" to me, somehow.  As if the pieces fit together especially well.  But I'm a neophyte solver.

I was really fortunate that the Magritte painting references is one of my favorites.  No, of course it's not a pipe--it's a painting.  Very playful and fun artwork.

I heard a story about OSIRIS, that HEWED early, ELOPED with EOS, who, as a godess, didn't know ELOTE bout cooking, and OSIRIS had to BEAR THE EXPENSE when she was continually saying, LETS EAT OUT. But you know the REST, he loved her and wouldn't TRADE her for the world.  It's not one of THOSE stories that MAKES HEADLINES, and it might not even be true, but it still makes my TOES curl.
Fell into the same trap as many with OPENENDED and SDS .  Once I had resolved that it was a very rapid Friday.  Close to my PB.
I liked this puzzle, but not sure how drone bees are a "caste".
Ok - two, too easy ??  I‚Äôm not complaining - with all the literal and figurative fires around us, I can use a reprieve.

I tried so hard to fit the Brady bunch, the Munsters or the Addams Family. Of course it was that modern Stone Age family from the town of Bedrock, the FLINTSTONES.

Easy Friday puzzle today.

Okay Ernest you are now my new favorite constructor ... 
You had me at The Flintstones. 

I still adore that show, best cartoon ever.

Anyway, I cannot wait for your next puzzle. I hope it's another creation that illustrates your wide interests.
Totally refreshing crossword. Almost every clue was unique. I really enjoyed the wordplay and the international flavor. I do hope you will be back soon Ernest you are a great addition to the NYT crossword family.

Hands down my favorite solve in 2025.
Hi Ernest great to know there‚Äôs a fellow NYT xword avid  here in sg. Was a joy solving your puzzle :)

Came here to PIPE in‚Äîproudly so‚Äîthat I got the line from Magritte without a single cross. Obsessions with art galleries and art history books and museums pay off sometimes over a cup of coffee and the morning crossword puzzle. Well, you guys get it. I let out a whoop followed by an explanation when I filled in the answer and only got a slightly pained look from my husband. He‚Äôs spent many hours in museum coffee shops while I sat cross-legged in front of successive paintings. Yes, now you‚Äôve met one of *those* people. (Se√±or Gato didn‚Äôt care either. Also, he‚Äôd never heard of ELOTEs but, Texas cat that he is, ALAMO was a gimme for him.)

If I may, I‚Äôd also like to crow that after a few short months as a temporary European, I filled in CELL for [mobile] thinking of the latter as‚Ä¶ a *noun.*

On second thought, maybe that‚Äôs something to lament, not crow about. Out here, mobile rhymes with exile.
I do hope Ernest continues to create puzzles, as I found this very enjoyable, something I can‚Äôt always say for themeless puzzles. My favorite entry,   THIS IS NOT A PIPE.
Shame about open endeD. SDS is easy enough to clue. Bet it makes a comeback in the near future.

Nice Saturday puzzle. Typical long workout for me, and had to cheat a bit in a couple of places, but ended up being an enjoyable solve as things finally dawned on me.

One of my favorite tattoos was borne by a young woman who had "ceci n'est pas un bras‚Äù in script along the inside of her forearm.

just waiting to be filled with riddles and

Solid and elegant debut!

Bravo!

Thank you Ernest!

Ernest, who lives in Singapore, says in his notes that he‚Äôs not familiar with most of the sports or cultural references ‚Äúthat are oh-so-common in The Times‚Äù.

I found the lack of these references refreshing in today‚Äôs grid.  Oh, there were cultural references, but ones that have stood the test of time: FLINTSTONES, ROSA PARKS, LLOSA, the Magritte painting, the Egyptian god ‚Äì answers that gave the puzzle a solid feel that I found comforting.

This is not to disparage the verve that comes from the au courant, which raises my pulse in a lovely way.  There are all kinds of good that puzzles can furnish, and today it was ‚Äúsolid‚Äù and ‚Äúcomforting‚Äù.

I liked the international flair in the box, with answers relating to France, Italy, Mexicao, Latin America, and Ireland.  I loved uncovering beauty: BEAR THE EXPENSE, PRESSED FOR TIME, MELEE, BOTCH, CANON, STATE PEN, DRIFT, SCRUM.  I liked seeing ELOTE sharing the grid with ELOPE, as well as the PuzzPairs¬© of CELL/STATE PEN and AXE/HEWED.   

Just a heap of loveliness to start the day, and that is a gift I never take for granted.  Congratulations on your NYT debut, Ernest, and thank you!
I thought OPENENDER was a slangy stretch. openendeD would be a descriptor.

Not too much time ELAPSEd while I did this puzzle - I was able to DRIFT between clues, EMENDing at times, and once the DUST settled, almost every CELL was correct.

‚Ä¶ though I did share the OPENENDEd problem with many people, having convinced myself that SdS was a weird abbreviation for students, and assumed commencement was some American start-of-school year thing, not realising that it‚Äôs almost the complete opposite !! Ah well, overall, great puzzle. LETS have more from this constructor !!

Wonderful debut with an inspiring story.  Love the alternate clue for 39D (LETS) which brings to mind another alternative, [Congressional approval]. 

Scroll down to about 9 hours previous to this post to see our newbie constructor checking in with more from the cutting room floor.

Yeah, lately the news does furrow my brow.


This quick but very enjoyable puzzle, not so much.
This felt like a Wednesday puzzle, which is exactly what I needed after yesterday's.

While I really enjoyed this puzzle, as I commented earlier, I'm surprised after reading all the comments that no one mentioned the very first 1D. I don't think I've ever heard it in the singular. Who's going to look at a bodybuilder and say "Wow, would ya look at that PEC!" Abs, yes, but not PEC. Though I didn't fill in abs, just waited for the easy crosses.

This was fast, but very fun. Really enjoyed 41A! The consideration of the audience balanced with the constructor's perspective is refreshing here as the pop culture references are so limited. There's something to be said for puzzles that aren't driven by a constructor digging in their own cultural niche.
Delightful puzzle, but what in God's name does "emend" mean?!?

this was weirdly hard for me, and i can't quite pin down why. i seemed to be on a totally different wavelength for almost every clue which left me with a LOT of empty squares and not much to build off, but it seems everyone else enjoyed the puzzle just fine, so it must just be me! a fine puzzle regardless though!

Re: 55A x 53D I saw the flap starting last night (link below). It didn't bother me. I was willing to accept -ER as a noun form of the much more common -ED adjective at 55A because I was a 1968 college graduate. There were, to be sure, members of SDS at our commencement, but they were there as individual SRS, not as a group. https://nytimes.com/shared/comment/44one5?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

Read "One paying half for quarters, say" and immediately filled in ROOMMATE, feeling very proud of myself ... Like many recently, this puzzle seemed a rather "gentle" Friday offering. Still, some interesting *words* here, like the symmetrically placed COWSHED and SEXTANT. COWSHED reminded me of visits to Fillmore Glen State Park in Moravia, NY (birthplace, more or less, of Pres. Millard Fillmore). Near the entrance to the park is lovely Cowshed Falls, and the adjacent "rock shelter" know as the Cowsheds. https://nyfalls.com/waterfalls/fillmore-glen-state-park/ Congrats on the debut!

I was among those who finsied quickly. All the while thinking 5D reminds me of a song..what is it? (Not the FLINTSTONES theme.) And it came to me "K-k-k Katy, beautiful Katy you're the only g-g-g girl that I adore. When the m-m moon shines over the COWSHED I'll be waiting at the k-k-k kitchen door." https://youtube.com/watch?v=0PSsXPXhTyM

This was an easy puzzle though I didn‚Äôt love OPENENDER, the single PEC, and EMEND. I am familiar with the word EMEND but I always think it so unnecessary, given the functional and phonetic similarity of amend. Plus, it looks awkward lol like it‚Äôs incomplete lol. Team amend.

ELOPE and REF always get fun clues and this puzzle is no exception!

I have to wonder if the constructor meant for OPEN ENDER to be clued as is poker term (that is commonly used and refers to a four card straight that you hope to draw into) instead of a 20 Questions term, but the editors changed it, sacrificing actual usage for more general context.

What a fun puzzle. 9D was an old friend, and filling it in gave me the feeling that everything would be OK. I loved the misleading clues (45D took awhile to get right). Was sure I would have to look up 38A but it turned out to be a "doh" moment. It's really refreshing to do a clever puzzle without those current cultural references that, ahem, puzzle some of us. Merci beaucoup for 30A. As for the to-do about 55A -- come on. It's a crossword puzzle. Some (other) constructors play with language as if it were taffy.

Congratulations to Ernest Lim. Let's have more from him.
Very easy for a Friday. Record time under 7 minutes. I know it‚Äôs not my imagination Friday/Saturday are definitely easier compared to years past‚Ä¶ I miss the challenge!
Fun puzzle, Ernest Lim! Thanks ~ )

I linked this in a reply below, but allow me to share one of my all time favorite pieces of music: https://youtube.com/watch?v=sV5qrp-FUto "Memento, homo, quia pulvis es" . . . especially while you're doing pec day at the gym. ("Remember, man, thou art dust.")

I searched Google for ‚Äúopen ender.‚Äù  iPhone autocorrect wanted to change ender to ended, and Google asked  ‚Äúdid you mean open ended.‚Äù  
BS answer, IMO, especially since there were perfectly valid clues for SDS on the cross.

Seems like others had trouble with OPENENDER/SRS. That one felt borderline mean honestly. Although the rest of the puzzle really did feel like a hard wednesday, which I am grateful for. If not for the aforementioned trouble spot this would have been my first gold start Friday. Thanks as always for the hard work, NYT Crossword team.
Fun, fun, fun!

I guess if there's no such thing as an OPENENDER question that would explain why no one ever asks one.

Fun puzzle! Fun notes!

Haven't seen Wicked yet but I assume OSIRIS is Cynthia Erivo's character.

Count me in with those who really enjoyed this debut by Ernest Lim. 

What struck me even more than the puzzle itself was Ernest‚Äôs journey to become a constructor. I thought Deb‚Äôs column was also very encouraging and inspirational for would-be constructors. Between them they made it sound like an achievable goal. As if maybe even a regular person like M. Biggen might one day create a NYT crossword. As if! I admit that the odds for me are probably low, but I suspect there are a great many of us here who have thought about it. And Ernest Lim did it!

Congratulations, Ernest! And thanks, Deb. Great column today.

I had no idea how ‚ÄúSing Sing‚Äù could be a STATEPEN until I googled it and found out it‚Äôs actually a penitentiary! For a moment I thought that along with a state bird, state tree, state flower, etc. that states were now declaring their favorite pens, haha

Like others, did not appreciate OPENENDER.  That's not a real thing.  Had SRS at first and then changed it to SDS to complete the cross, thinking this was an abbreviation I just didn't know.  Nope - you just made up a word to make your puzzle work!  Also didn't know about CBC so had CBS for a while.  Overall, though, a fun puzzle with fair crosses.

Enjoyed the clue for EXITPOLLS.
38 Across brought a smile as I said another TV Clue.  Then I got crosses.  Wow!  Fun!  Thanks, Mr. Lim!  A Fun Friday!  Keep writing puzzles!
A pretty good Tuesday puzzle!

This was a mix of do-able and very chewy for me; it helped that 9D was a gimme for instance, as was BLEUS, but the crossings of 30 and 35 with 32D was a killer. No clue for city, media group or why a Drone bee answers as CASTE. 

Overall an enjoyable grid with some pretty chewy entries. My final error, which added about 6 minutes to my time was mis-spelling ROB for Rub. Oops.

Our COWSHED is about to be converted to an Alpaca shelter. Going to see my potential new additions next week. Those eyes. Those eyelashes. Sigh, I‚Äôm so in love.

Didn‚Äôt love the single PEC (I‚Äôve never heard anyone refer - with pride, no less - to only one of their pecs!) OPENENDER or EMEND (spare me the smug lectures) but 36D [One paying half for quarters, say] is the clue of the year thus far. Well done, Mr. Lim!

I was able to solve this one with just a few lookups! I am learning that I will need to learn a little Spanish, French, Latin, and Greek gods and goddesses if I ever want to regularly solve a late-week puzzle.
Meet George Jetson, Jane, his wife...no, that's not right. And of course, the Canadian Broadcasting Company would have French programming. The BBC, not so much.

A nice puzzle generally, but I agree with the protests about open ender.  Clearly meant to trip up the solver when there was an alternate correct answer. Not quite fair. ( Especially when it ends a 25-day streak!) Moreover, the meaning of open-ended (an adjective) is clear. Open ender (adjective plus noun?) seems pretty vague.
You know how when you get a tricky one right away and feel pretty proud of yourself?  Today it was UMP for ‚ÄúMake some calls?‚Äù‚Ä¶ which of course turned out to be wrong.

Many enjoyable clues, but my favorite was 9D! A great debut! Thanks for sticking with it, Ernest!

A very fun and breezy puzzle, on the easy side for a Friday. I tied my best time for a Friday to the second!

Love the editors efforts to branch out to new constructors and I don't want to write discouraging comments to them. Can easier puzzles be placed earlier in the week and let us crotchety solvers have our challenges on Friday and Saturday?

Oops..I did the puzzle around 7:30 CST, but neglected to Comment--just went  straight to check my email, etc., only to find a "joke" that felt Too Soon.  Considering where we are living (Deep in RED Country) I shouldn't be surprised, except why would someone send this to ME?  

So, now it's almost 11 a.m., so I am sitting down to today's French Lesson.  (I don't "get" a couple of other clues, on top of that.)  I tried ROUGE, then BLANC, and finally BLEUS, reluctant about the pluralization.  Pfft!

For the record, Drone bees are MALES, and when winter comes, they are expendable.  I don't extend human morality to the lives of insects, so the idea of CASTE doesn't fit for me if you want to use bees as the example.  We do see plenty of humans that can be characterized as "drones"--contributing nothing to our society, serving little purpose and allowing society to BEAR THE EXPENSE...  but let's not talk about the parallels, eh?

The WOOD of cypress trees is also impervious to insect attack and long-lasting.  Mostly, the decks I see are made of treated WOOD (stained to look something like CEDAR) or the new fake wood.....  

I'm out of inspiration.

A fun puzzle featuring my two favorite interests (equestrian center and Magritte) and the name of one of my Great Danes! (23D)

Thank you Mr. Lim and welcome back Mr Shortz.

Overall the puzzle was pretty good! Of course I always believe it‚Äôs good if I can solve it in less than an hour lol! The one thing that really tripped me up was 33- since I thought it was AMEND and not EMEND. Perhaps it‚Äôs due to my current Vertigo and the current state of affairs that scare me lol! Hopefully you all have a wonderful weekend and namaste!! xo
Thank you Mr. Lim for this breezy, easy and interesting Friday puzzle." More please"  as someone famous once begged.
Emend?? OpenendeR??? Oof. Somehow I still came under my Friday average, but still, it‚Äôs the principle of the matter!

Once backstage someone had put a sign on the wall which said "Do NOT put ANYTHING on this table!"   However, the table had been moved and replaced by a hamper. I don't speak French, but I was rather chuffed that I found the proper font and made a sign for the hamper which said "Ce n'est pas une table."

Fun puzzle, great debut. I was fine with OPENENDER, although I agree it would have been better clued as the poker term. And yes, I do use the word EMEND with some frequency.
Living in rural Wisconsin all my life I‚Äôm pleased to report that never in my life have I heard the words ‚ÄúCOW SHED‚Äù.

Reading over the comments this morning I have concluded that my complaint last night that the puzzle was too easy for a Friday was harsh. The puzzle was, as they say, in my wheelhouse. I solved it while I was listening to a Warriors game (they won!!) and still finished the puzzle in less than 30 min.  

A big help was my second fill, the Magritte pipe, which made so many crosses much easier. The S in the god of the afterlife gave me OSIRIS, even though it was news to me that his skin was green.  Pollack's art accessory‚Äîat first I thought of brush, then EASEL emerged from a cross.  I don't know many three-letter Greek goddesses and the ights went on with EOS.

So many long fills that juped out with a few letters made the whole puzzle much easier, but it seems to have been one of those times when the constructor (thank you Mr. Lim) was an old friend and we were talking about the same things. Many puzzles that were a breeze to other solvers have been a trial for me.

The whole puzzle may have been a quick solve, but it was rich with good cluing.  Thanks again, Ernest, and forgive me if I seemed dismissive.

(I many start sobbing when Saturday puzzle arrives.  Ya just never know.)
coincidence ? - answer is "this is not a pipe" and then later in the arts section we see a photo entitled "this is not a cigarette"

Late puzzle finds. Two puzzles with unusual themes by the same constructor and they actually shared some answers, though clued completely differently in each puzzle. Anyway - one - a Wednesday from March 10, 2004 by Richard Silvestri. This one was all in the clues - note something specific in each of the clues: "Wedding man lookin' at the newspaper?" READINGROOM "Durable piece of boxin' equipment?" EVERLASTINGLOVE "Result of a silo tippin' over?" FALLINGRAIN Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/10/2004&g=20&d=A And the other one, also by Silvestri - a Sunday from May 14, 1995 with the title: "Municipal Bonds." Again - it was all in the clues. Some examples: "Michigan monoliths :" FLINTSTONES "Illinois college :" NORMALSCHOOL "Colorado bylaw :" GOLDENRULE "Alabama residence :" MOBILEHOME And there were several others. Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/14/1995&g=97&d=A I'm done. ...

I hate to be one of those people, but in art speak ‚Äútone‚Äù is a color mixed with grey and ‚Äútint‚Äù is a color mixed with white. If you were changing the tone of a color you would be tinting it for the first time, not RETINTing it. Right? Or should I EMEND my thinking on this?

Beat my average by 37%.

Is COWSHED the past tense of COWSH?

On my trips alone to Paris (my favorite way to travel) I stayed in a ** hotel, cheap but very clean and friendly, where there were other English speaking guests‚Äîa Canadian prof, who had stayed in the hotel right after WWII while he was finishing his degree; a reporter who was taking a week-end break from her rocky romance in Denmark; and an Angelino, who had dreams of being "discovered" at the Cannes Film Festival. One evening when we all sharing a bottle of wine at the hotel, the young woman from L.A. was showing us her new lace gloves, frowned, turned and to me and said,"I know you don't shop, so what do you do all day?"

@Elizabeth Ross I feel like the person whose tattoo your saw, as well as the author of the clue for 9D, has missed the point of "The Treachery of Images". As the title suggests, the point of the caption is that the image of a pipe is not itself a pipe. It would be a lie to say "this is a pipe" ‚Äî it's not a pipe, it's a mere representation of a pipe. This isn't a paradox.

The tattoo you saw was a paradox, though. The arm is an arm, not a mere representation of an arm. So labelling it "this is not an arm" isn't a clever reference to the difference between signifier and signified, like Magritte's painting, but simply transferring his caption to a place where it is no longer appropriate.
